p: Human diet and therapy have featured valuable plants gathered from the wild since ancient times. The agricultural civilization developed in the past 12,000 years has been founded on the domestication of many useful species [ 1]. However, in the modern era, global economic considerations have significantly changed agricultural approaches and scales, which brought about overexploiting of land resources, consistent diminishing of natural biodiversity and negative modifications of human diet and health [ 2, 3]. Globalization and urbanization have accelerated the unification of the current human diet and have led to a further narrow hoard of available useful species [ 4]. The recent burst of noncommunicative diseases (NCD), including obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disorders and cancer among populations of developing countries as well as lower socioeconomic classes of developed countries, is largely attributed to nutritional and health disorders derived from current human diets [ 5].
